[109] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What did Airbnb report as its free cash flow for the last twelve months (LTM) and its corporate cash and investments balance as of the end of Q2 2025 in the Q2 2025 shareholder letter or earnings release? A: Airbnb reported LTM (TTM) free cash flow of $4.3 billion and corporate cash and investments of $11.4 billion as of June 30, 2025 (reported as “cash and cash equivalents, short‑term investments, and restricted cash”). (news.airbnb.com, inkl.com)

[110] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Has Airbnb published a cross‑jurisdiction compliance report or other public disclosure describing how it complies with local licensing, consumer‑safety, and worker‑classification rules for its vetted services and experiences, and if so what jurisdictions or key compliance metrics are listed? A: Short answer: No — as of Aug 7, 2025 Airbnb has not published a single, consolidated cross‑jurisdiction “compliance report” that systematically maps how Services & Experiences comply with local licensing, consumer‑safety, and worker‑classification rules. Instead it publishes host-facing standards (vetting, license/insurance, safety requirements), localized rollouts/City Portal tools and city‑specific registration notices (e.g., France/Berlin/networks of cities), and legal/regulatory disclosures (including worker‑classification risks) in SEC filings and transparency reports. (airbnb.com, news.airbnb.com, sec.gov) If you want, I can search specific jurisdictions (e.g., NYC, UK, Portugal) and pull the Airbnb pages or local rules that Airbnb cites.

[111] Research Agent 🔍 Q: How many shares did Airbnb retire or repurchase as part of the $1.0 billion repurchases completed in Q2 2025 as reported in the Q2 2025 shareholder letter, and did the company disclose an expected or projected change in outstanding share count related to the additional $6.0 billion authorization? A: Airbnb repurchased and subsequently retired 8.1 million Class A shares for $1.0 billion in Q2 2025. (sec.gov) The company announced an additional $6.0 billion repurchase authorization but did not disclose any expected or projected change to its outstanding (or fully diluted) share count tied to that new authorization (it only reported the historical decline to 652 million fully diluted shares at 6/30/2025). (news.airbnb.com, sec.gov)

[112] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Has Airbnb published a buyback prioritization policy or disclosed any explicit linkage between the newly authorized $6.0 billion repurchase program and executive compensation targets in its proxy statement, shareholder letter, or other public filings, and if so what linkages were disclosed? A: Short answer: Yes and no. - Yes — Airbnb has publicly stated the buyback is part of a capital‑allocation prioritization (invest in organic growth, strategic acquisitions where relevant, then return capital to shareholders), including in its shareholder letters and SEC filings describing the $6.0B repurchase authorization. (fintel.io, cdn.yahoofinance.com) - No — I found no explicit disclosure tying the newly authorized $6.0B repurchase program to executive‑compensation targets or payouts in the company’s proxy statement, shareholder letters, Form 10‑Q/10‑K or other public filings through Aug 7, 2025. The proxy describes compensation metrics (bonus plan, equity awards, CEO performance RSUs) but does not link those metrics to share‑repurchase activity. (sec.gov) If you want, I can pull the exact passages and page/line citations.

[122] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Have any third‑party academic papers or municipal studies attributed measurable changes in long‑term rental supply to Airbnb host conversions around major events, and if so what were the quantified effects on long‑term rental stock or vacancy rates reported by those studies? A: Short answer: I could not find a third‑party academic or municipal study that specifically isolates major events (e.g., Olympics, big concerts) as the causal trigger for permanent host conversions and then reports a quantified change in long‑term vacancy rates. Academic work has, however, measured Airbnb’s aggregate effects on long‑term supply: e.g., Horn & Merante (Boston) find a one‑SD rise in Airbnb listings → ~5.9% fewer rental units offered; Barron et al. estimate a 10% rise in Airbnb listings → ~0.39% higher rents and show listings shift supply from long‑ to short‑term. Municipal/industry reports document large event‑period listing spikes (Paris 2024, etc.) but generally do not report causal, persistent vacancy‑rate changes tied to event‑driven conversions. (sciencedirect.com, pubsonline.informs.org, airbnb.com) If you want, I can run a targeted search for any city‑level post‑event housing reports (e.g., Paris, Rio, host cities) and check for vacancy‑rate estimates.

[169] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What full‑year 2025 adjusted EBITDA margin target did Airbnb state in its Q2 2025 materials, and did the company explicitly state that the target includes approximately $200 million of investment in new businesses? A: Airbnb’s Q2 2025 materials set a full‑year Adjusted EBITDA margin target of at least 34.5%. Yes — the company explicitly said that guidance is inclusive of roughly $200 million of investment in new businesses (some filings described the planned spend as $200–$250 million). (news.airbnb.com, sec.gov)

[170] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What reduction in human support contacts did Airbnb attribute to its AI customer‑service agent in the Q2 2025 shareholder letter or earnings release (reported percentage), and over what measurement period was that reduction measured? A: Airbnb said the AI customer‑service agent cut the share of hosts and guests who needed to contact a human agent by 15%. The Q2 2025 shareholder letter states this reduction occurred “during the quarter” as the agent was expanded to 100% of U.S. users (Q2 2025). (news.airbnb.com, marketscreener.com)

[171] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Did Airbnb disclose a net‑debt / EBITDA cap or other leverage target or ceiling in its Q2 2025 investor materials, and if so what numeric target or cap was stated? A: Yes. In its Q2 2025 earnings materials (Aug 6, 2025) Airbnb said its long‑term Net Debt / Adjusted EBITDA target is about 2–3x. It also disclosed a covenant ceiling after a credit‑facility amendment: 5.25x through Q2 FY2026, stepping down to 5.00x in Q3 FY2026, 4.75x in Q4 FY2026 and 4.50x in Q1 FY2027 and thereafter. (sec.gov, sec.boardroomalpha.com)

[172] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Did Airbnb disclose an average price per share for the $1.0 billion of Class A stock repurchased in Q2 2025, and if so what was the disclosed average repurchase price per share? A: Yes. In Airbnb’s Q2 2025 Form 10‑Q (three months ended June 30, 2025) the company reported repurchasing 8.1 million Class A shares for $1.0 billion and disclosed an average price paid per share of $124.20 (includes broker commissions). (sec.gov, news.airbnb.com)

[173] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What Q3 2025 revenue guidance range did Airbnb provide in its Q2 2025 shareholder letter or earnings release (reported dollar range)? A: Airbnb guided Q3 2025 revenue of $4.02 billion to $4.10 billion in its Q2 2025 shareholder letter/earnings release (issued Aug. 6, 2025). (news.airbnb.com, reuters.com)

[174] Research Agent 🔍 Q: In Q2 2025 public filings or investor materials, did Airbnb commit to providing standardized APIs for third‑party agents or integrators (for example registration or booking APIs for city governments or vendor agents), and if so what API specifications or rollout timelines were disclosed? A: Short answer: No. Airbnb’s Q2 2025 public filings and investor materials do not announce a new, company‑wide commitment to ship standardized registration/booking APIs for cities or third‑party agents, nor do they publish API specifications or a rollout timeline in those materials. (sec.gov) Context: Airbnb already offers government tools (City Portal) and runs partner/API programs (with program requirements such as NDAs, security review and a six‑month implementation rule for released features), but those are existing programs rather than a new Q2 2025 commitment with public specs or timelines. (airbnb.com) If you want, I can search city‑specific agreements (e.g., France, Sacramento) or the full Q2 slide deck/transcript for any finer details.

[175] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What average rating did Airbnb report for Experiences/Services in its Q2 2025 disclosures (for example the ≈4.93 figure cited informally), and what reporting period and sample size were provided for that rating? A: Airbnb said the average guest rating for its re‑launched Services/Experiences was about 4.93 out of 5 “since launch” in its Q2 2025 earnings materials. It referred to the metric as measured “since launch” (the Summer Release launched May 13, 2025) but the Q2 press materials and earnings transcript do not provide a precise measurement window or a sample size (number of bookings/reviews) for that 4.93 figure. (marketscreener.com, news.airbnb.com)

[176] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What media‑reach figures did Airbnb report for the ‘2025 Summer Release’ in its Q2 2025 shareholder letter or earnings materials (specifically the number of articles and total impressions reported), and did the company provide any breakdown by geography or channel? A: Airbnb said its May 2025 “2025 Summer Release” generated “more than 13,000 press stories” (≈13,000 articles) and “nearly 660 million social media impressions” in its Q2 2025 earnings materials (shareholder/earnings release published Aug 6, 2025). (news.airbnb.com, marketscreener.com) I could not find any breakdown of those media figures by geography or by channel (e.g., platform-level social split) in the shareholder letter or the earnings‑call remarks. (news.airbnb.com, marketscreener.com)

[193] Research Agent 🔍 Q: As of August 6, 2025, has Airbnb disclosed in any public filing or investor presentation a repurchase framework that conditions share buybacks on verifiable compliance milestones (for example city MOUs/API rollouts, percentage of vendor audits meeting SOC‑2, or AI agent SLA/escalation metrics); and if so what specific milestones, thresholds, and citation(s) were provided? A: Short answer: No. As of August 6, 2025 Airbnb’s public filings and investor materials announce board‑authorized repurchase authorizations (a new $6.0B program on Aug 6, 2025) but describe repurchases as made “at management’s discretion” and “subject to market and economic conditions, applicable legal requirements and other relevant factors.” They do not condition buybacks on verifiable compliance milestones (city MOUs/API rollouts, SOC‑2 vendor audit thresholds, AI‑agent SLA/escalation metrics) or list specific milestone thresholds. (sec.gov, investors.airbnb.com) If you’d like, I can search older filings, investor decks, or earnings‑call transcript excerpts for any narrowly worded language you’re worried might be interpreted as milestone‑linked.

[194] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Beyond open‑ended language that repurchases ‘may be made from time to time,’ did Airbnb publicly disclose any prescriptive buyback execution framework in Q2 2025 filings or subsequent 8‑K/proxy (for example an annual tranche cap, valuation trigger, minimum cash floor, or leverage trigger); and if so what specific numeric thresholds and filing citations were provided? A: No. In the Q2 2025 Form 10‑Q (quarter ended June 30, 2025) and in the 2025 definitive proxy, Airbnb disclosed only discretionary, open‑ended repurchase language (repurchases “may be made from time to time…,” authorization dollar amounts and amounts executed/remaining). The filings do not set prescriptive execution triggers, annual tranche caps, minimum‑cash floors, valuation/price triggers, or leverage limits with numeric thresholds. (See the “Share Repurchase Program” / Item 2 (Use of Proceeds) and Note 13 (Subsequent Event) in the 10‑Q; and the DEF 14A proxy discussion of repurchases). (sec.gov) If you want, I can pull the exact 10‑Q paragraphs and highlight the wording and line citations.

[195] Research Agent 🔍 Q: As of August 6, 2025, has Airbnb publicly disclosed service‑level objectives (SLOs) and end‑to‑end surge‑test results for its rebuilt platform that report p95 latency and error‑rate for vendor APIs, onboarding queue depth, and AI→human handoff; and if so what metric values and reporting dates were published and where? A: Short answer: No — I could not find a public, single disclosure from Airbnb (as of Aug 6, 2025) that publishes end‑to‑end surge‑test SLOs covering p95 latency and error‑rate for vendor APIs, onboarding‑queue depth, and AI→human handoff together with numeric values and formal reporting dates. What is public: - Airbnb’s engineering posts describe their load‑testing framework (Impulse; Jun 9, 2025) but don’t publish a consolidated set of SLO numbers or end‑to‑end surge test result tables. (medium.com) - An Airbnb AI support post (Aug 10, 2021) gives a p95 model‑inference example (~60 ms for a ~1.1B‑param model) — that’s a model latency datapoint, not a full platform SLO suite. (medium.com) - Business/earnings disclosures note AI rollout and impact (50% U.S. users on the AI agent; ~15% fewer live escalations) but do not publish the requested p95/error‑rate/queue‑depth SLO matrices. (news.airbnb.com, techcrunch.com) If you want, I can run a deeper search (press releases, GitHub, conference talks, regulatory filings) for any narrow/hidden report or contact links.

[196] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Has Airbnb published municipal‑ or ZIP‑level metrics such as ‘host income by ZIP’ or ‘services vendor payroll’ that quantify local economic impact or uplift from Events and Services; and if so which jurisdictions and what metric values and reporting periods were disclosed? A: Short answer: Yes—Airbnb publicly posts city/metro/county/state-level economic‑impact reports (host earnings, guest spending, jobs, tax revenue) for specific places and years (e.g., U.S. 2024 and 2023 reports; Austin, Atlanta, Colorado counties). (news.airbnb.com) No—there is no publicly posted, company‑published dataset that systematically reports “host income by ZIP” or a “services/vendor payroll” series tied to Airbnb Events/Services as of Aug 7, 2025. Airbnb has historically shared occasional neighborhood figures with press (examples exist from earlier years) but granular ZIP‑level or vendor‑payroll tables are not published publicly; instead Airbnb provides more detailed, private data access to governments via its City Portal. (businessinsider.com, news.airbnb.com) If you want, I can (a) run a deeper search for any city‑specific ZIP breakout or (b. request sample City Portal fields reported to jurisdictions.

[197] Research Agent 🔍 Q: As of August 6, 2025, has Airbnb published measured per‑trip revenue uplift or RevPAR increases attributable to Services/Experiences cross‑sell (for example incremental revenue per trip or RevPAR lift) in any shareholder letter, earnings release, or investor presentation; and if so what uplift percentages, baseline definitions, sample sizes, and reporting periods were disclosed? A: Short answer: No. I found no shareholder letter, earnings release, or investor presentation from Airbnb through Aug 6, 2025 that publishes a measured per‑trip incremental‑revenue percentage or RevPAR lift explicitly attributable to Services/Experiences cross‑sell — Airbnb’s Q2‑2025 materials describe “early momentum,” ratings and host application counts but do not report uplift percentages, baseline definitions, sample sizes, or reporting periods. (investors.airbnb.com, news.airbnb.com) Notes/sources: Airbnb’s Q2‑2025 financial results and press release (May launch of Services/relaunched Experiences; mentions ratings and >60k host applications) and linked investor materials show qualitative/aggregate metrics (Nights/Seats Booked, GBV, ADR) but no quantified per‑trip or RevPAR cross‑sell lift. (news.airbnb.com, investors.airbnb.com)

[198] Research Agent 🔍 Q: Has Airbnb publicly reported same‑day fulfillment, same‑day cancellation, or same‑day refund rates for vetted Services/Experiences since launching in‑trip browsing or the 2025 Summer Release; and if so what were the reported same‑day fulfillment and same‑day cancellation/refund percentages and the reporting period?
